title: Friday, 12th February, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE

Hello, hi, welcome, hey there.

BE

And it's an up-day Friday, meaning we can start with a distraction.

BE

So if you've been on Twitter over the past 24 hours, you'll no doubt have seen https://www.what-dog.net/

11:06 am
BE

An algorithmic, automated dog-breed identification system.

BE

One of Microsoft's sideline projects

BE

(And one does wonder why Microsoft's sideline projects are so much better than their core projects.)

11:07 am
BE

(If they could do fewer dog identification systems and fix .Net Framework, that'd be cool.)

BE

To be fair, though, it's pretty accurate ......

BE

11:07 am
BE

Have a play in your own time.

undefined
BE

So yes, bear-market rally.

11:08 am
BE

FTSE ahead 74 points at 5611.

BE

And it's best expressed by charts.

BE

First, here's the FTSE 350 normalised to the start of 2015

11:08 am
BE

With the sub-indices for mining (yellow), banks (green), life (pink) and E&P (red) broken out.

BE

BE

(Right click and open in new tab to make that legible.)

11:09 am
BE

And here's the same chart normalised to the start of 2016

BE

BE

Fall most, bounce most.

11:10 am
BE

(@Boncoeur: philosophy goes beyond my remit here.)

BE

And finally, here's that nearly symmetrical daily moves chart

BE

FTSE 350 again, from the start of time.

11:10 am
BE

BE

So volatility happens in clusters. Stuff that falls a lot bounces furthest. The usual.

undefined
11:11 am
BE

Speaking of ........

Rolls-Royce Holdings PLC (RR.:LSE): Last: 610.64, up 80.64 (+15.22%), High: 614.00, Low: 585.00, Volume: 9.62m
BE

It doesn't warn!

11:12 am
BE

Not explicitly, anyway.

BE

But Rolls results are always a three-pipe problem.

BE

The accounting treatments take quite a lot of work to understand.

11:13 am
BE

But it's a Friday, and who wants to do work?

BE

(@Boncoeur: argue away. I always welcome the challenge to actually think about stuff, rather than just relying on my own half-arsed assumptions.)

BE

Headline EPS beats, 2016 guidance no worse than November. 50% divi cut already flagged.

11:14 am
BE

So shares up 15%. Bosh. Everyone'e happy.

BE

Happy, at least, providing you don't look too closely at the detail .....

BE

Where the EPS is 58.7p against a consensus of 54.7p

11:14 am
BE

But that includes the sale of IP for £58m -- which, bafflingly, is included in the Ebita figure.

BE

Exclude that and 2015's basically in line.

BE

Albeit with revenue missing by a tad. £13.35bn vs £13.63bn.

11:15 am
BE

Free cashflow positive though!

BE

£179m vs -£38m consensus.

BE

Though ....... uh ........... that also includes the £58m IP sale one-off.

11:15 am
BE

The FCF beat also reflects Rolls placing the thumb screws on its customers for early payment.

BE

Probably on the concern that they're quite likely to go bust.

BE

Which has a pull-forward effect on 2016.

11:16 am
BE

2016 FCF guidance is for £-100m to £-300m. Consensus was for £127m.

BE

And while the 2016 outlook is in line, it's not entirely in line.

BE

Here's Cazenove.

11:17 am
BE

 2016 EPS likely to be c5% below current consensus for three
reasons: (1) RR is guiding to Civil Aero EBITA of £262m, vs consensus
(median) of £286m. (2) The 2016 finance charge will be c£90-110m, vs
consensus (median) of £80m. (3) The underlying tax rate will be c26%,
up c1.5% yoy as the geographic mix changes.

BE

(@roddy1234: well .... the range was so stale, the median and mean consensus are quite far apart. Perhaps we should just ignore consensus entirely.)

BE

 Our first reaction: With 2016 EPS and FCF below expectations, a rich
valuation, and outperformance of the shares in 2016 YTD, we expect the
shares to underperform over the rest of the year.

11:18 am
BE

 Valuation: Rolls-Royce currently trades on 2016E P/E of 18.6x, 2016E
clean P/E of 30.1x and 2016E clean EV/EBITA 25.9x as at COB
February 11, 2016.

BE

Thirty times clean 2016!

BE

Ah, hell. Have some more sellside.

11:19 am
BE

None of which can agree on whether the numbers were above, below or in line.

BE

And none of which can agree whether forecasts are going up, down, or staying the same.

BE

Seems to me that, with Rolls, you pay an unintelligibility premium.

11:20 am
BE

Here's RBC.

BE

EPS of 58p (sort of) – 4p beat: Rolls-Royce has reported full-year 2015 results, with underlying diluted continuing EPS of 58.3p comparing with the consensus forecast
of 54p, and our forecast of 51.5p. Group underlying PBT of £1,432m compared with consensus of £1,300m. However, the underlying number was boosted by a couple of one off items, and so underlying underlying PBT was £1,355m with EPS of 55.5p, in line with the lower end of company guidance for the year. Free Cashflow was +
£179m, above the guidance mid-point of break even. The company left its trading outlook for 2016 unchanged, and cut the dividend by 50%

4Q results better than expected: Versus our forecasts, overall revenues were below our expectation by around 1%, with a notable shortfall in Power. The company
noted the negative impact of oil & gas. However, margins were strong at 11.2%, driven by outperformance in Defense (19.3%) and Energy (10.2%), boosted by the release of an R&D credit. Civil was also helped by a one off accounting adjustment of £189m. Aftermarket revenues were organically flat, with Trent up and RB-211 down. Rolls continues to manage the issue of old widebodies coming out of service, with Malaysia and TransAero being two airline customers that are struggling at the moment. Underlying finance costs were also lower than expected, offset by a higher tax rate of 24.5%. As noted above, FCF was + £175m, though Rolls benefitted from the pull forward of 2016 cash receivables.

2016 guidance unchanged: Rolls has maintained its trading outlook for 2016. This includes a forecast of a cash outflow of £100-300m, and EBIT £650m down, or £727m down versus the underlying 2015 number with the one off items. Civil still has its mix transition, and Marin is still set to be hit by the energy market downturn.

OUR VIEW: Considering how low expectations were, the fact that Rolls beat consensus for the period and maintained its 2016 guidance is probably being seen as a massive upside surprise. Even the dividend cut had been widely flagged, so is not outside of reasonable expectations. The mother of all short squeezes is no doubt helping the stock, but when the dust settles we think investors are likely to still remain cautious given the numerous multi-year issues that Rolls is tackling – but at least they haven’t got worse.

BE

And Barclays.

11:20 am
BE

Revenue of £13.4bn was at the bottom of guidance, PBT of £1,432m was higher than expected but in line with expectations when adj. for exceptional; £58m IP settlement, £19m tax credit. FCF at the top end of guidance aided by capex cuts and earlier than expected customer receipts. The dividend cut of 50% to 7.1p (14.1p in FY14) was as expected. Net debt £111m (£666m net cash in FY14). Of most interest however and what is likely driving the sharp move in early trading, is the £0 trading cash flow in Civil aero vs. the confirmation by the company that Civil was a notable cash outflow at the November CMD. Explanation around this point will be a key focus of the call, but given the TotalCare Net Debtor is now guided to peak at £2.5bn (prior guide c £2.2bn, and will probably slip a year to the right in our view) this may imply the unexpected Civil cash is from engines outside of TotalCare.
While the FY16 outlook has been maintained, we’re still lacking detailed FY16 guidance.
The -£650m headwinds remain (exc the £58m one off), but we’re not provided with banded guidance at this point. We expect further clarity to come throughout 2016 as we hear more about the Strategic Review, in advance of which we are still lacking some clarity around FY16 and the medium term. In the interim, we’ve seen the first positive print for a long while which is clearly reflected in early trading, but the risks around cash and the lack of guidance do not appease our concerns at this juncture.
Increasing Total Care Net Debtor guided to £2.5bn, up from £2.1-2.3bn in November, will likely support earnings in the short term, but following news flow about Boeing last night, we expect the treatment of contract accounting to be an enduring line of questioning.
Valuation 18.2x 2016 PE, 13.2x 2016 EV/EBIT

BE

And Jefferies, which is shop.

BE

FY16 outlook. We anticipate many companies will express caution and probably guide quite broadly for FY16. RR’s FY16 guidance by division is not given in ranges as before, but through commentary that we believe is just as helpful. Our interpretation of the commentary for FY16 divisional EBIT is: Civil Aerospace £262m (JEFe £250m; Consensus £295m), Defence around £350m (JEFe £370m; Consensus £367m), Marine – guided to be “significantly loss-making”, but still £75m to £100m below FY15 (as stated in last November’s IMS), so loss of around £75m (JEFe -£80m; Consensus -£78m), Power Systems around £200m (JEFe £170m; Consensus £198m) and Nuclear & Energy around £50m (JEFe £45m, Consensus £46m). After Central Costs of, say, £50m, we figure RR’s FY16 commentary points to a Group EBIT of around £737m. That compares with JEFe of £700m and consensus of £748m. There is obviously scope for fine-tuning of forecasts, but maybe we can agree there is no profit warning involved. On FCF, the FY16 guidance is for an outflow of £100-300m, versus JEFe -£180m and Consensus -£166m. RR’s guidance reflects some of the FY15 beat being a matter of timing, in our view. On the dividend, RR has signalled the FY16 interim will also be cut by 50%. We venture the FY16 dividend is more likely to be around 11.7p to 12.0p than our forecast of 15.5p.

Headwinds, but progress. As promised last November, RR has provided the gross margin, overheads and R&D for each division. For Civil Aerospace, RR also shows the divisional trading cash flow - £0 in FY15 versus £181m in FY14. The FY15 cash flow is as we estimated, but a cash flow model based on a known number should be more compelling, in our view. The analysis of both Civil Aerospace OE and Services sales by Widebody Linked, Widebody Unlinked, Corporate and V2500 will also allow us to inject more certainty into our model. For example, knowing that FY15 Widebody Services revenue was £2,371m confirms our TotalCare cash flow model to have a sound starting point. We also venture that a more detailed analysis will help us estimate OE engines losses.

Stopping the rot. If sentiment stabilises and a more rounded approach to gauging the RR equity story is adopted, we believe it will bring cash flows into focus. RR has stated that cash flows are the best way of valuing Civil Aerospace – and we agree. The story is simple – rapid growth in the installed engine fleet generates corresponding strong growth in aftermarket revenues, but expenditure on engine overhauls initially grows far more slowly. We believe these variables are widely understood. We remain optimistic FY16 will show momentum is building, the hurdles - like Trent XWB unit cost - are being overcome and, to be blunt, that RR management has control and is growing in confidence.

11:22 am
BE

And MOST, which is the other shop.

BE

Sensible action on the divi; boxes ticked on extra disclosures: In light of
near-term pressures on FCF and given the desire to keep a healthy BS (net
debt £111m at 31 Dec 2015) and strong investment grade credit rating, Rolls
has announced a final divi of 7.1p (a 50% reduction yoy) taking the full year
divi for 2015 to 16.4p (consensus 17p; MSe 13.7p). A potential 2016 cash
outflow for divis of £300m (MSe £250m) is therefore implied. At the same
time Rolls has indicated that the 2016 interim divi will also be reduced by 50%
yoy, implying 4.6p. Rather than guide on the 2016 final divi as well however,
Rolls plans to review the payment in due course with a view to rebuilding it
over time to an "appropriate" level. Were we to assume a flat final divi in 2016,
it would imply 11.7p for the full year (consensus 15.9p; MSe 14.2p); however,
clearly Rolls' hope is that easing short-term cash needs and confidence in the
future cash generation of the business will allow a return to growth. Finally, we
welcome the additional disclosures in the results release which will require
further analysis, most notably gross profit and cost line items by division, as
well as a trading cash flow bridge for Civil (showing £0m for 2015).

undefined
11:24 am
BE

(@TFT1, I figured it was that secondary effects eclipse the primary benefits.)

BE

(As in, oil-related counterparty risk for financials and suchlike, as well as stunted SWF involvement.)

BE

(But we're an open house for theories.)

11:25 am
BE

Now, I wish there was something new to say about this mining rally ......

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 355.60, up 39.65 (+12.55%), High: 358.20, Low: 323.75, Volume: 4.47m
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 94.42, up 6.74 (+7.69%), High: 95.55, Low: 88.13, Volume: 30.03m
11:26 am
Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 414.30, up 24.8 (+6.37%), High: 415.50, Low: 390.60, Volume: 1.23m
Vedanta Resources PLC (VED:LSE): Last: 222.30, up 13.4 (+6.41%), High: 222.58, Low: 210.20, Volume: 320.87k
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 1,806, up 101 (+5.92%), High: 1,814, Low: 1,703, Volume: 2.56m
11:26 am
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 674.40, up 40.3 (+6.36%), High: 683.30, Low: 640.40, Volume: 4.02m
BE

However, it's just the usual amplification of market trend stuff.

BE

I can through some Barclays sector research at you, but it's space filler rather than anything contemporaneous.

11:28 am
BE

Liquidity and solvency are likely to be increasingly important differentiators as the
next stage of the commodity cycle plays out. Declining commodity prices combined
with multi-decade high leverage has left a growing number of companies at risk of a
solvency crisis. These companies have debt maturities over the next three years
exceeding available liquidity and net FCF generation on spot, leaving them in the
hands of their creditors in the absence of further management action. Meanwhile
debt and increasingly equity markets are closed: we note only BHP and RIO have fiveyear
bond yields below 10% currently among the traded debt of the European mining
sector. As seen in the US coal industry, high liquidity can prove illusory when
commodity prices fall further than expected, leading to permanent impairment of
capital structure. In this note we examine which companies are vulnerable if spot
prices decline further and what they can do in response.

BE

(@WhenIWereYoung: bloody hell. Apologies.)

BE

Who could be in danger if prices continue to fall? We have created a financial and
operational index to assess how likely it is that the companies come through the next three
years broadly intact assuming spot commodity and currencies, plus downside scenarios.
On this analysis, Ferrexpo, KAZ Minerals, Vedanta and First Quantum appear to be most
at risk. If commodity prices fall from spot levels, Vale and BHPB start to look vulnerable.

11:28 am
BE

But most have levers to pull: KAZ Minerals has the bulk of its debt provided by the CDB,
which is likely to extend flexibility on maturities, albeit at a potential cost to shareholders.
FQM is trying to sell assets and may finally defer capex on Cobre Panama. Vale could be in
danger if commodities fall further, but it has asset sales underway (with risks attached)
and can probably rely on state banks for additional facilities if required. Anglo has ample
liquidity for now but needs to act quickly to address its challenges with options for asset
sales/closures, spin-offs and an equity raise (see Time is of the essence). Under a 20%
haircut to spot commodity prices, BHPB’s liquidity headroom looks increasingly thin. Only
RIO looks relatively safe, a position bolstered by its dividend cut announced yesterday.

BE

Equity recommendations: We continue to favour the less leveraged miners Rio Tinto
(OW) and Rangold (OW, Top Pick). We maintain UW ratings on Anglo American, BHPB,
Vale, Vedanta, KAZ Minerals and Ferrexpo: equity issuance and debt restructuring at
the expense of equity holders remains a high risk for most of these names if commodity
pricing doesn’t improve and/or asset sales prove elusive.

BE

Credit recommendations: After a recent rally, we see risk of widening in Anglo
American (AALLN) 5y CDS and consider Teck Resources (TCKBCN) to be a possible
comp; in cash, AALLN trades roughly 5pts higher than TCKBCN, but the basis in 5y CDS
is roughly 13pts.

11:30 am
undefined
BE

And, with a sense of fatality, from miners to banks.

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 153.85, up 6 (+4.06%), High: 156.05, Low: 150.30, Volume: 25.02m
11:04 am
BE

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing.

Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 231.20, up 7.7 (+3.45%), High: 231.70, Low: 225.40, Volume: 4.78m
HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 430.30, up 10.15 (+2.42%), High: 433.95, Low: 424.95, Volume: 7.74m
11:32 am
BE

There seems to be a growing acceptance, on twitter and the email round robins at least, that bank investors losing their money is not a crisis.

BE

A crisis is when bank depositors lose their money.

BE

Which we're nearly certain won't happen, specifically because bank investors are losing money.

11:32 am
BE

Bank stocks are pricing in an increased likelihood of their AT1s being converted, which is a consequence of earnings stagnation. That's just hedging.

BE

That's exactly how the system is supposed to work.

BE

And if things get worse .... If it turns out that Barclays needs to bump its CET1 up from the current 11.1%, for instance, it can just zero the divi.

11:33 am
BE

Which'd move CET1 up to nearly 14% by end 2017

BE

Not getting a divi is not a crisis.

BE

There are levers to pull that can release solvency and liquidity. Those levers are not nice for holders of equity, bonds or indeed cocos (which, I'm interested to note, everyone is suddenly an expert in).

11:34 am
BE

Still, though. That's not. A. Crisis.

BE

Today's notable bank upgrade comes from Investec.

BE

Ian Gordon knife catching StanChart.

11:35 am
Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 410.20, up 23.55 (+6.09%), High: 417.80, Low: 393.35, Volume: 3.84m
BE

Given the way 2016 has played out so far, we think it is little surprise that STAN has been (almost) the worst performing UK bank YTD. Aside from its disproportionate ($43.2bn) commodities-related exposure, with adverse implications for revenues and impairments, the blow-out in CDS spreads and yields for AT1 securities has implications for its intended $4bn of further AT1 issuance. Our clear preference for Aldermore (Buy) and Virgin Money (Buy) remains, but on 0.4x 2015-17e tNAV our absolute STAN rec moves to BUY.

BE

Our forecasts remain below consensus by a considerable margin, though we are not entirely convinced this is particularly meaningful. Our (unchanged) revenue forecasts of $15.7bn in 2015e (down 14% YoY) and $14.4bn in 2016e (down a further 8% YoY) and $14.7bn in 2017e (+2%) remain below Bloomberg consensus by 6% in Q4 2015e, and by 7% in both 2016e and 2017e.
We have moderately increased our impairment assumptions in anticipation of fresh deterioration, primarily driven by the commodities-related exposures. In Q3 2015, STAN posted what was for it a “record” impairment charge of $1.4bn (an annualised 2% of average customer loans) including a notable element of NPL coverage build, strengthened from 54% to 58%. Our revised forecasts for impairments are $4.3bn (1.6%), $3.4bn (1.4%) and $2.0bn (0.8%) through 2015-17e with the scale of anticipated “improvement” reflecting (already) lower impairments in Retail coupled with a more limited incremental coverage build.
STAN issued $2bn of AT1 securities in 2015 with a coupon of 6.5%. It plans a further $4bn over time, but given market conditions we assume this will (of necessity) be delayed, and will ultimately need to offer a much improved yield.
Our EPS forecasts of 2c, 6c and 51c for 2015-17e are now 77%, 15% and 34% below Bloomberg consensus of 8c, 7c and 77c through 2015-17.
We believe that STAN’s path back to “normalised” returns remains long and deeply uncertain. However, trading at a fresh 21st Century low of 387p, equivalent to 0.4x 2015-17e tNAV, we raise our recommendation to Buy (from Hold), while our RoE-g/CoE-g-derived target price falls to 460p (from 550p).

11:38 am
BE

(@R7039275: as Leggie says, volumes seem very poor below the ~£500m level. Perhaps there's a bit of retail reticence linked to the fact that we're still a few months away from end of the tax year.)

undefined
BE

Okay, what else do we have?

11:41 am
BE

BE

BE

11:41 am
BE

BE

BE

11:44 am

BE

11:45 am
BE

BE

"operational issues"

Premier Oil PLC (PMO:LSE): Last: 31.85, up 2.1 (+7.06%), High: 32.75, Low: 30.00, Volume: 2.80m
11:47 am
BE

Premier and Noble Energy entered into a contract with Ocean Rig in 2014, for the Eirik Raude drilling unit for an exploration drilling campaign in the Falkland Islands. Following a number of material operational issues with the Eirik Raude rig, Premier and Noble Energy issued a termination notice to Ocean Rig on 11th February, terminating the contract with immediate effect. As a result, Premier will no longer drill the Chatham exploration well during the current campaign and discussions are ongoing with the Falkland Islands Government regarding the possibility of drilling this prospect in the future.

BE

Let me see if there's any sellside around that does more than mark the news.

BE

Davy, perhaps?

11:48 am
BE

Premier Oil and Noble Energy have terminated the rig contract for the Eirik Raude rig after both companies experienced operational issues with the rig during the 2015-early2016 drilling campaign off the Falklands. As a result Premier will now not drill the Chatham prospect during the current campaign. Premier is in discussions with the Falkland Islands Government regarding the possibility of drilling this prospect in the future. Premier has a 60% interest in the Chatham prospect which has gross estimated prospective resources of 34 mmboe (unrisked). The prospect is considered a western gas cap of the Sea Lion oil field.

BE

No ... not really.

BE

FirstEnergy?

11:49 am
BE

The contract for the Ocean Rig is being terminated with immediate effect. Th is reflects technical difficulties with the rig. As a result, Premier will no longer be drilling the Chatham exploration well during the current campaign. Market Reaction: N‎eutral. This is of limited materiality. However assuming there are no penalties to terminate the contract, this might trigger some minor capex reduction.

BE

No, not really.

BE

Nope. Seems no one cares. Sorry.

11:49 am
undefined

BE

11:51 am
BE

Downgrading Tullow and M&P.

Tullow Oil PLC (TLW:LSE): Last: 149.90, up 2.5 (+1.70%), High: 157.20, Low: 147.70, Volume: 4.89m
BE

11:53 am

undefined
BE

11:54 am
BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 446.20, down 4.25 (-0.94%), High: 451.65, Low: 442.30, Volume: 9.02m
BE

UBS downgrade.

BE

Competition.

11:54 am
BE

We think the potential downside could be £1.25bn pa (-15%) to longer-term EBITDA, coming from Sky entering the mobile market and the merger of Vodafone/Liberty Global

BE

Wait, what?

BE

Can BT deliver more cost savings?
Yes. Potentially, EE cost synergies could be greater than £540m pa vs guidance of £360m pa. Separately, we see scope for BT to realise greater than £330m pa of stand-alone cost savings. However, it is not clear how much of this will be re-invested…

11:55 am
BE

But what about the bit about Vod-Liberty?

BE

Because they've, you know, denied that's currently happening ....

BE

Will Openreach be structurally separated?
Unlikely. However, we think Ofcom could outline the need for tougher regulation

11:55 am
BE

Super.

BE

(@Greedy_When_Others_Are_Fearful: I'll do what I can.)

BE

So let's jump forward to page 13 for the fantasy M&A section.

11:56 am
BE

After numerous talks in 2015, Vodafone and Liberty Global recently announced
that they are in talks about creating a JV in the Netherlands that would see each
party inject their Dutch operations. However, we note that the overlap between
the two companies is much broader than just the Netherlands and we believe a
deal in Netherlands would not preclude a broader deal at a later stage. We think
discussions about the Netherlands are happening now given T-Mobile Netherlands
was reportedly up for sale, with Liberty Global involved in the process according to
reports in De Telegraaf (3 February 2016). Separately, Liberty Global needed to
move sooner rather than later to stem underperformance in its Dutch unit, which
has been impacted by competition from KPN. With Liberty Global in the process of
acquiring CWC for greater than $4bn in equity value, it may be difficult to resume talks on a
broader deal until the CWC deal completes in Q2 2016. It is not clear what
structure any potential deal could take and the options include asset swaps
between the two companies, a merger of equals or a take-over of Liberty Global
by Vodafone. Regardless of how a deal is structured, we think the benefits of a
combination would be:

BE

§ A stronger converged operator: Strategically the deal would combine
complementary fixed-line and mobile assets, particularly in Germany, UK and
the Netherlands. The resulting entity would be one of the leading converged
players in markets such as the UK, Germany, Spain, Netherlands and Belgium.
§ Significant financial synergies: Based on benchmarks from other recent
fixed-mobile deals, cost synergies could be £0.9-1.6bn pa with an NPV of £8.5-
14.2bn (for 100% of the synergies). In addition we see scope for tax synergies
of £4.6bn.

Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 202.45, up 1.85 (+0.92%), High: 203.20, Low: 201.45, Volume: 16.13m
11:56 am
BE

All of which has been UBS's argument for at least a year, to be fair.

BE

And I guess is a secondary concern. So let's jump back up to the top.

BE

Here's the upshot of the BT stuff.

11:57 am
BE

Risk/reward profile unattractive
BT is well-run and has created significant shareholder value. But at this point we see the
risk/reward profile as unattractive and think the risks from increasing competition have
been underestimated. We cut our rating to Sell from Neutral. Our base-case PT is 430p
– our estimates are broadly in line with consensus and assume a continuation of the
current benign competitive environment. However, should competition intensify we see
downside to 305p. We see scope for BT to realise additional cost savings, but the
upside scenario is only 490p. We acknowledge the potential for BT to be a beneficiary
of cross-border M&A, but this is likely to be in the longer term.

BE

Competition set to increase? UBS Evidence Lab helps quantify downside
After a benign period, we see a risk of increasing competition that could lead to longerterm
EBITDA for BT being £1.25bn pa (-15%) lower on a downside scenario – we use
UBS Evidence Lab data to help quantify the downside. On mobile, Sky is set to launch a
mobile service later this year and, depending on the remedies from the Hutchison/O2
UK merger, there could also be a new entrant such as Iliad. A potential
Vodafone/Liberty Global merger would lead to lost MVNO/BT Wholesale revenues
initially, but we think the longer-term impact from Virgin Media’s footprint expansion
(Project Lightning) has been underestimated.

BE

Scope for additional cost savings but upside could be offset by re-investment
BT has an exceptional track record on cost savings. We see scope for BT to increase EE
merger synergies to greater than £540m pa (vs guidance of £360m pa) at its Q4-16 results, and BT
has reiterated its intention to realise greater than £330m pa of stand-alone cost savings. However,
what is not clear is how much of this will be re-invested (into customer service/BT
Sport/etc), and capex at EE is likely to be higher than consensus expects given upfront
investment for the Emergency Services Network (ESN) contract. On Openreach, we do
not expect it to be structurally separated. While this outcome might initially be greeted
with relief, we think Openreach is likely to be subject to increased regulation, including
charge (price) controls on fibre (GEA), but this is not in our base case.

for Vodafone and Sky.

BE

Canaccord Genuity just reported a Q3/16 adjusted operating loss of -$0.25/share, well below our +$0.01/share forecast and well below consensus
expectations for a loss of -$0.02/share. In addition, the Company has elected to suspend the quarterly dividend ($0.05/share) temporarily in light of
challenging market conditions and business activity levels. The suspension will be reviewed quarterly on the basis of business conditions and profitability.
Key metrics we believe investors are focusing on for Q3/16 results are:
l Revenues of $182MM were slightly below our $188MM forecast. Revenues were up 9% Y/Y from $166MM in Q3/15.
l Compensation ratio was 71.1% of revenues, worse than our 60.6% forecast and worse from 60.4% Q2/16. The compensation ratio was affected by
increases to certain bonus pools for key staff to adjust for weak market performance.
l Non-compensation expense ratio was 37.8% of revenues, worse than our 33.3% forecast and worse from 34.2% in Q2/16.
